title: A great start, but...
text:
There are many things I love about this app
1. It's not a huge hive of right-wing idiots talking about how great their ideas are. This is unfortunately what Twitter has devolved into and why I left it. 
2. The layout is very user friendly and feels smooth and intuitive. 
3. Most interactions on the app result in learning something and not feeling like a complete IQ drain, which you can't say about Twitter. It feels like there is meaningful interactions, which gives the app itself purpose.

However, there are several issues that need to be worked on for this app to be truly great, and here is what they could be in my opinion:

1. Set up a better search function so that it is easier to find topics and ongoing things that you are interested. 
2. Make it easier to find people and topics that you are interested in by building on the integrated search functionality.
3. Although the "For you" section of the app is good, I think there needs to be a rework in what people can choose what they would like to see instead of just basing the content based off of what you like and follow already.

So to sum it up, it is good and not great so far and has a long way to go to be truly awesome.

title: A few things
text:
1.	Adjustable Text Size: Provide users with the option to modify the size of the text within the application‚Äôs interface, allowing for customization based on individual preferences.

2.	Profile Photo Zoom: Implement functionality that enables users to click on a profile photo, triggering a larger view of the image for better visibility and detail.

3.	Dim Mode: Introduce a dark blue-themed dim mode within the application, offering an alternative visual style that is less intense than the typical night black mode.

4.	Hashtags: Incorporate support for hashtags, enabling users to add and search for specific topics or themes by utilizing relevant hashtags within the application.

5.	Following-Only Feed: Create a separate feed within the application that exclusively displays content from users that the current user follows, providing a personalized and tailored experience.

6.	Trending Page: Implement a dedicated page that showcases trending topics, hashtags, or popular content within the application, allowing users to stay informed about popular discussions and current trends.

title: I love Threads!

title: Frustration Galore
text:
I can honestly say that the app is a nightmare. As an avid user who relies on platforms like this for news, updates, and connections, I am utterly disappointed.

The app's performance has hit an all-time low. It lags, freezes, and crashes constantly, making it nearly impossible to have a smooth browsing experience. It's as if the developers took a promising app and intentionally wrecked it.

And don't even get me started on the algorithm! The prioritization of irrelevant and repetitive content is mind-numbing. I followed accounts for a reason, but they are rarely shown, while suggestions that I have no interest in flood my feed. It's an infuriating waste of time.

The app also bombards users with endless ads and sponsored content, effectively killing the authenticity and charm of the platform. This invasive approach feels greedy and reflects a lack of respect for users' time and attention.

In conclusion, the app has become a breeding ground for frustration. Its glitches, algorithmic failures, lack of action against harassment, excessive ads, and poor UX have turned a once-promising platform into a colossal disappointment. Unless drastic improvements are made, I cannot recommend this app to anyone seeking a worthwhile social media experience.

title: Interesting discussions
text:
Text-based social networking. Short posts with or without photos.

I‚Äôve curated two feeds‚Ä¶ one for US politics and one for climate action and nature photography, and am finding both to be good places to stay informed and connect with other people who share the same interests. I‚Äôve had useful conversations with experts (and the only time I‚Äôve had an uncomfortable interchange was with one of those experts so I just pass on by her posts). More fun has been the opportunity to get to know everyday climate activists from other parts of the world and support each other‚Äôs efforts. 

Unless you‚Äôve gathered a pretty large following, commenting on other people‚Äôs posts is generally more effective at generating conversation than quote posting or posting a new thread. 

It‚Äôs easy to avoid celebs, trolls, porn, etc by blocking accounts or just not interacting with them. You get more of what you follow, like and reply to.

title: An Unorganized, Jumbled Mess
text: Threads in its current iteration is a random collection of unsorted and unsortable conversations among people I don't know and mostly don't care to know. Why do I follow people or have followers? I cannot actually follow anyone unless I navigate (tediously) to their profile page and scroll down at threads they created or re-threaded. That is just too cumbersome to provide an enjoyable experience. For example, I welcomed a dozen or so folks that cover my favorite college teams. But, now that Threads has scale, I rarely ever see their posts, excuse me, threads. Oh, I can still find their comments - - - over on Twitter in my Sports List. Threads is like I am at a cocktail party, incognito, overhearing conversations and feeling like I just want to leave.

title: Eh..
text: I didn‚Äôt realize you couldn‚Äôt delete without deleting your instagram. Not cool. I would like it if it wasn‚Äôt just a bunch of influencers in my feed. Same with the other app. I follow people I want to see. I don‚Äôt need to see ONLY influencers. I don‚Äôt mind a few sprinkled in (I do enjoy their content), but it‚Äôs all that I see. I have real friends I follow on there and they are nowhere to be found. I deleted Twitter long ago, so I probably should‚Äôve realized it would be the same to me. It‚Äôs just annoying seeing all the same influencers sharing their same content on every app. I miss seeing people I want to interact with. Most of them don‚Äôt even interact with us peasants‚Ä¶

title: In theory good, in practice not so much
text:
When I first installed it, it was fine, did what it‚Äôs supposed to. After a couple days, I couldn‚Äôt view any replies to posts, any posts of a (public) user, it was basically worthless. Keep getting ‚ÄúSomething went wrong, try again‚Äù error or ‚ÄúContent not available‚Äù. Tried all solutions but none worked, so I had to delete the app. Hopefully a future release will fix this problem because I really want to use it.

I also was bothered that upon installation, many of my Instagram followers ‚Äúrequested‚Äù a follow (which is an automatic thing upon install?). It would be nice to differentiate who actually clicked a follow button, and who did the automatic follow request.

title: Money before the users.
text: The app first appeared to be a well structured version of Twitter and I had high hopes for this app, until the moment I reached the home page. The main home page is filled with nothing but posts from people I don‚Äôt even follow. I understand these big companies need to make money and paid posts are a thing as much as we hate them. But the thing that‚Äôs most annoying is that we thought this would be an app for us IRL friends to connect with one another by allowing us to choose not to follow celebrities or big companies but yet we can‚Äôt get away from them and my friends posts are nowhere to be seen. Feels like just another big tech app putting money before the users.

title: A Moderation and Privacy Disaster
text:
For the past several weeks, Instagram has been banning my 13 year-old account that I mostly use to read family members‚Äô updates  every 5-7 days. I send them the ‚Äúproof of life‚Äù photo, they review my account and say ‚Äúwhoops our bad‚Äù and restore the account. Then a week later they make the same mistake. Rinse and repeat.

Do you want to give access to a company that is that incompetent all your personal data? Scroll down to the description of what information this app collects about you. That‚Äôs not necessary to run a short posting service. It is necessary to run a business where they sell your data to other businesses.

Meta/Facebook/Instagram shouldn‚Äôt be trusted to do anything in your best interest, and they know A LOT about you.

text: So I had left a review about how it didn‚Äôt let me load things as in comments followers pass a certain point and I wasn‚Äôt able to find everybody‚Äôs reply on messages and I wasn‚Äôt able to get notifications after a certain point. I posted some thing and I can‚Äôt load more than six of the replies after that, the same goes for when I look through other peoples post and when I go to my notifications, it doesn‚Äôt even show the notifications that I‚Äôm receiving for that post anymore. I‚Äôll receive them on my phone but that‚Äôs as far as I get I can‚Äôt tell who‚Äôs replying or posting after I loginto Threads

title: Possible improvements
text: Good start but could be fleshed out a little more. I really hope they make it easy for you to switch between accounts like Instagram does so you don‚Äôt have to log out and log in every time. It‚Äôs also easy to switch apps from threads to Instagram but not visa-versa. Threads has an Instagram logo top right to switch easily but to switch from Instagram to threads there is no such shortcut. I would also like to possibly see a your all caught up divider so you don‚Äôt mindlessly scroll the threads you seen before.

title: Great UI, garbage feed
text: The UI is constrained, thoughtful and masterfully engineered ‚Äî a world-class product. Only upstaged by a relentless stream of the trashiest influencers who have ever roamed this scorched earth. There‚Äôs no escaping the Kardashian wannabes breaking news regurgitaters, as they fill my feed with garbage I never asked for. Why oh why would you treat such a well designed app with such disrespect? Oh, I know. Because the name of the game is maximum attention. It‚Äôs only a matter of time before the ads are interleaved between the celebrity trash talk. Then the only step left is to optimize the algorithm to maximize fear and anxiety to increase stickiness. Oh Meta, it‚Äôs so so clear where you‚Äôre taking us and it‚Äôs so disappointing.

title: In the year of our lord 2023
text:
In the year of our lord 2023, an age in which social media timeline apps have been around for nearly 2 full decades, how can one of the world‚Äôs most powerful and wealthy social media companies mess up a simple timeline app so badly? Constantly, bugs. Your timeline will routinely be spammed with the same tweet/thread, over and over. Posts never render linearly, and always the top post after refreshing will be hours old, often 10+ hours old. The content pumped to you is repetitive and cringe.

Facebook has completely over engineered what people want - a linear timeline with interesting but simple text and photo content for the educated masses who just don‚Äôt want to be surrounded by Musk idiots. What Twitter used to be. But threads has missed the mark, badly.
